lines.text: "To be or not to be?" That is the question which preoccupies our people, Captain Kirk. We need breathing room.
Earth, Hitler, 1938.
I beg your pardon.
Well... I see we have a long way to go.
You don't trust me, do you? I don't blame you. If there is to be a brave new world, our generation is going to have the hardest time living in it.
only Nixon could go to China.
Mr. Scott, I understand you're having difficulty with the warp drive. How much time do you require for repair?
There's nothing wrong with the bloody thing...
Mr. Scott, if we return to Spacedock, the assassins will surely find a way to dispose of their incriminating footwear, and we will never see the Captain or Doctor McCoy alive again.
Could take weeks, sir.
Thank you, Mr. Scott.
[Dictating his personal log]

I've never trusted Klingons, and I never will. I could never forgive them for the death of my boy. It seems to me our mission to escort the Chancellor of the Klingon High Council to a peace summit is problematic at best. Spock says this could be an historic occasion, and I'd like to believe him, but how on earth can history get past people like me?
If I were human I believe my response would be "go to hell." If I were human.
Course heading, Captain?
Second star to the right and straight on till morning.
Spock, you want to know something? Everybody's human.
I find that remark... insulting.
[on whether to help the Klingons]
They're animals.
Jim, there is an historic opportunity here.
Don't believe them. Don't trust them.
They're dying.
Let them die!
[pauses... Spock cocks his head in surprise. Kirk recoils and proceeds]
Has it occurred to you that this crew is due to stand down in three months? We've done our bit for king and country! You should have trusted me.
[Watching a replay of the torpedo hit]
It is Enterprise. We fired them.
That is not possible! All weapons visually accounted for, sir.
An ancestor of mine maintained that when you eliminate the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth. If we did not fire those torpedoes, another ship did.

[prosecuting]
Dr. McCoy, would you be so good as to tell me? What is your current medical status?
Well, aside from a touch of arthritis, I'd say pretty good.
[some scattered laughter from the audience; McCoy smiles, but sees Chang, unsmiling]

[unamused]
You have a singular wit, Doctor.
[Kirk and company have prevented the assassination attempt at Khitomer]
What's happened? What's the meaning of all of this?

It's about the future, Madame Chancellor. Some people think the future means the end of history. Well, we haven't run out of history quite yet. Your father called the future - "the undiscovered country". People can be very frightened of change.
You've restored my father's faith.
And you've restored my son's.
Logic, logic, logic. Logic is the beginning of wisdom, Valeris, not the end.

[over the public address speakers]
"I am constant as the northern star."
I'd give real money if he'd shut up.
[last lines]
[Kirk's final Captain's Log]

Captain's Log, stardate 9529.1. This is the final cruise of the Starship Enterprise under my command. This ship and her history will shortly become the care of another crew. To them and their posterity will we commit our future. They will continue the voyages we have begun, and journey to all the undiscovered countries, boldly going where no man... where no *one* has gone before.
[the Excelsior is knocked off course by a huge shockwave, and Commander Rand intercepts a message from the Klingon moon Praxis]

[in Klingon]
This is an emergency! We have suffered...!
[the message abruptly cuts off, replaced by the seal of the Klingon Empire, and then Kerla's face]

This is Brigadier Kerla speaking for the High Command. There has been an incident on Praxis. However, everything is under control, we have no need for assistance. Obey treaty stipulations and remain outside the Neutral Zone. This transmission ends now.
An *incident*?
Do we report this, sir?

[turning to Rand]
Are you kidding?

[dictating his personal log]
The Enterprise hosted Chancellor Gorkon and company to dinner last night. Our manners weren't exactly Emily Post. Note to the Galley; Romulan Ale no longer to be served at diplomatic functions.
I don't understand. If there was another ship underneath us, surely the assassins beamed aboard from that vessel, not Enterprise.

You're forgetting something, Mr. Chekov. According to our ship's databanks, this ship fired those torpedoes. If we did, the killers are here. If we did not, whoever altered the databanks is here. In either case, what we are looking for, is here.
You understand, we have lost all contact with the Captain and Dr. McCoy.
Yes, at the moment, they are surrounded by a magnetic shield. However, if I know the Captain, by this time, he is deep into planning his escape.
[Cut to Captain Kirk on the losing end of a fist fight with an alien at least twice his size]
Bones, are you afraid of the future?
I believe that was the general idea that I was trying to convey.
I don't mean this future.
What is this, multiple choice?
I can see you, Kirk.
Chang.
Can you see me? Oh, now be honest, Captain, warrior to warrior. You do prefer it this way, don't you, as it was meant to be? No peace in our time. "Once more unto the breach, dear friends."
"Cry havoc, and let slip the Dogs of War."
A Bird-of-Prey?
A Bird-of-Prey.
Cloaked?
A Bird-of-Prey cannot open fire when she's cloaked!
All things being equal, Mr. Scott, I would agree with you. However, all things are not equal. This one can.
I'm going to sleep this off. Please let me know if there's some other way we can screw up tonight.
I'm gonna find myself a pot of black coffee.
Well, most kind... parting is such sweet sorrow. Captain, have we not heard the chimes at midnight?
In space, all warriors are cold warriors.
Valeris, know anything about a radiation surge?
Sir?
Chekov?
Only the size of my head.

[to himself]
I know what you mean.
You have not experienced Shakespeare until you have read him in the original Klingon.
"taH pagh, taH be?"
[after Kirk wins a fight against an alien twice his size]
They'll respect you now.
That's a comfort. I was lucky that thing had knees.
That was not his knee.
[Kirk looks at Martia in surprise]
Not everyone keeps their genitals in the same place, Captain.
Anything you want to tell me?
[Martia smiles at Kirk]
[the crew enter the bridge]
Once again, we've saved civilization as we know it.
And the good news is they're not going to prosecute.
They might as well have prosecuted me. I felt like Lt. Valeris.

[looks at Spock]
Well, they don't prosecute people for having feelings.
Just as well, or we'll all have to turn ourselves in.
Nice to see you in action for one last time, Captain Kirk. Take care.
Doctor, would you care to assist me in performing surgery on a photon torpedo?
Fascinating!
In range?
Not yet sir.
Come on, come on.
She'll fly apart!
*Fly her apart then!*

[referring to Gorkon's daughter, whom he believed killed Gorkon]
That Klingon bitch killed her father.
Her own father?
It is an old story, sir.
They don't place the same value on life as we do, Spock. You know that. Mark my word, she did not shed one bloody tear.
Hardly conclusive, Mr. Scott, since Klingons have no tear ducts.
Mr. Scott?

[over intercom]
Aye, sir?
Did you find the engine room?
Right where I left it, sir!
Bones, I'm wearing a veridium patch on my back! Spock slapped it there just before we went on Gorkon's ship!
Why, that cunning little Vulcan!

[Spock has beamed Kirk and Bones aboard just before they find out who framed them]
No! No! Of all the - son of a - Couldn't you have waited two seconds? They were just about to tell us the whole thing!
You want to go back?
Absolutely not!

[whispering]
It's cold.
And this is General Chang, my chief of staff.
I have... so wanted to meet you, Captain.
I'm not sure how to take that.
"We stand ready to assist you" - Captain Sulu, USS Excelsior.

[on the viewscreen]
Captain Sulu! You realize that just by talking to me, you're violating regulations?
I'm sorry, Captain, your message is breaking up...
Bless you, Captain.

[to Valeris]
What you want is irrelevant, what you have chosen is at hand.
What we require now is a feat of linguistic legerdemain and a degree of intrepidity before the Captain and Dr. McCoy freeze to death.
[after Kirk and Martia kiss passionately]
What IS it with you, anyway?
Still think we're finished?
Now, more than ever!

Two months ago, a Federation starship monitored an explosion on the Klingon moon, Praxis. We believe it was the result of over-mining and insufficient safety precautions. The moon's decimation means a deadly contamination of their ozone layer. They will have depleted their supply of oxygen in approximately fifty Earth years. Due to their enormous military budget the Klingons do not have the resources to combat this catastrophe. Last month, at the behest of the Vulcan ambassador, I opened a dialogue with Gorkon, Klingon chancellor of the High Council. He proposes to begin negotiations at once.
Negotiations for what?
The dismantling of our starbases and outposts along the Neutral Zone, an end to nearly 70 years of unremitting hostility which the Klingons can no longer afford.
[In a conversation with Spock]
You're a great one for logic. I'm a great one for rushing in where angels fear to tread. We are both extremists. Reality has brought us somewhere in-between.
The lieutenant was the first Vulcan to be graduated at the top of her class.
You must be very proud.
I don't believe so.
She's a Vulcan all right.

[to Uhura]
Guess who's coming to dinner.
[Quote adaptation from the Cuban Missile Crisis of 1962]

Indeed. The record shows that Captain Kirk once held the rank of Admiral. And that Admiral Kirk was broken for taking matters into his own hands in defiance of regulations of the law. Do you deny being demoted for these charges? DON'T WAIT FOR THE TRANSLATION. Answer me now.

The Chancellor of the High Council is dead - the result of an unprovoked attack while he traveled to see you under a flag of truce on a mission of peace. Captain Kirk was legally arrested for the crime. May I remind you that he and Dr. McCoy boarded Kronos One on their own free will? No of these facts are in dispute, Mr. President.
I have ordered a full-scale investigation. In the meantime...
In the meantime, we expect the Federation to abide by the articles of Interstellar Law, which you claim to cherish. Kirk and Dr. McCoy will stand trial for the assassination of Chancellor Gorkon.
Out of the question.
[to Sarek]
Ambassador Sarek, there must be some way to extradite these men.
Mr. President, I share a measure of personally responsibility in this matter, but I am obliged to confirm my esteemed colleague's legal interpretation.
What is the position of the Romulan government, Ambassador Nanclus?
I must concur with my colleagues.
But you can't possibly believe that James Kirk assassinated the Chancellor of the High Council.
Mr. President, I don't know what to believe.
I'm waiting for your answer, sir.
This president is not above the law.
We must inform Starfleet Command...
Inform them of what? A new weapon that's invisible? Raving lunatics, that's what they'll call us! They'll say we're so desperate to exonerate the captain that we'll say anything.
And they would be correct. We have no evidence, only a theory which happens to fit the facts.
"Tickle us, do we not laugh? Prick us, do we not bleed? Wrong us, shall we not revenge?"
You are Crewman Dax?
Yes Commander. What is the problem?
Perhaps you have heard Russian epic of Cinderella? If shoe fits, wear it!
[drops magnetic boots at Dax's feet]
Mr. Chekov...
[camera pans down to show that Dax's feet are incapable of fitting into boots]
What are we all doing here?
Maybe they're throwing us a retirement party.
That suits me. I just bought a boat.
This had better be good. I'm supposed to be chairing a seminar at the Academy.
Captain, isn't this just for top brass?
If we're all here, where's Sulu?
*Captain* Sulu, on assignment. Where's Spock?
Where's that damn torpedo?
It's ready, Jim. Lock and load!

[clenches fist]
Fire!

[an energy wave has buffeted Excelsior]
Don't tell me that was any meteor shower!

[checking the scanners]
I've confirmed the location of Praxis, but...
What is it?

[turning to face Sulu]
I cannot confirm the existence of Praxis!

[pointing to the image on the viewscreen]
Praxis?
What's left of it, sir!

[Valeris has just engaged thrusters to take Enterprise out of Spacedock]
Thank you Lieutenant, ahead one quarter impulse power

[spins in chair to face Kirk]
Captain, may I remind you that regulations specify thrusters only whilst in spacedock.

[the bridge crew cough loudly, Chekov shakes his head, Uhura tuts softly. McCoy leans in to tease Spock]
Jim?
You heard the order, Lieutenant...
Aye, sir!
You're Kirk and McCoy, I presume.
How did you know that?
We don't get many presidential assassins.
We didn't kill Gorkon!
Of course not. But there is a reward for your death.
That figures.

This is the gulag Rura Penthe. There is no stockade. No guard tower. No electronic frontier. Only a magnetic shield prevents beaming. Punishment means exile from prison, to the surface. On the surface, nothing can survive. Work well, and you will be treated well. Work badly, and you will die.

[seeing the Enterprise]
Shields up! All right, now we've given them something else to shoot at.
Arrest those men!
Arrest yourself!

[last words to Kirk before death]
Don't let it end this way, captain.

[after seeing the Enterprise's torpedo hit the Bird-of-Prey]
Target that explosion and fire!
[His ship is about to be destroyed by The Enterprise]

[last words]
To be... or not to be?
[Spock and McCoy are heading for the Torpedo bay]
Bet you wished you'd stood in bed!
Names, Lieutenant!
I do not remember.
A lie?
A choice.
[Considering a military strike against the Klingons]
Suppose you precipitate a full-scale war?
In that case, Mr. President, we can clean their choronometers.
Mr. President, they are vulnerable... there will never be another time.
The longer we wait, the less successful the hostages will be, sir.
[Kirk is fighting with Martia disguised as Kirk]
I can't believe I kissed you.
Must have been your lifelong ambition.
[as soon as Azetbur finishes her transmission to the Federation President, Kerla unrolls war plans on her desk]
Attack them now, while we still have the chance!
Attack them, or be slaves on their worlds!
We can take whole by force what they propose to divide.
War is obsolete, general... as we are in danger of becoming.
I don't know whether to congratulate you or not, Jim.
I wouldn't.
Let us redefine progress to mean that just because we can do a thing, it does not necessarily mean we must do that thing.
Sir, those men have literally saved this planet.
Yes Bill, I know that. And now they're going to save it again... by standing trial.

[Fighting Martia who has changed to look like him]
Isn't it about time you became something else?
I like it here.
[first lines]

Stardate 9521.6. Captain's Log, USS Excelsior. Hikaru Sulu commanding. After three years, I have concluded my first assignment as master of this vessel, cataloguing gaseous planetary anomalies in Beta Quadrant. We're heading home under full impulse power. I'm pleased to report that ship and crew have functioned well.
Is it possible that we two, you and I, have grown so old and so inflexible that we have outlived our usefulness?

[to Lt. Valeris]
Lieutenant, the torpedo hit, once again, please.
[Valeris replays video]
Hold.
[replay pauses]
It *is* Enterprise. *We* fired.
That is *not* possible! All weapons *visually* accounted for,
[to Spock]
sir.
An ancestor of mine maintained that if you eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth.
What, exactly, does *that* mean?
It means that we can not have fired those torpedoes, someone else did.
Well, they dinna fire on themselves, and there were no the ships present.
There was an enormous neutron energy surge.
Not from us!
A neutron surge that big could only be produced by another ship.
Kronos One?
Too far away. Very near *us*. Possibly *beneath* us.
If there were a ship beneath us, the Klingons would have seen her.

[pause]
Would they?
A bird-of-prey.
A bird-of-prey.
*Cloaked?*
A bird-of-prey cannot fire when she's cloaked.
All things being equal, Mr. Scott, I would agree. However, things are not equal. This one *can*.
We must inform Starfleet Command.
Inform them of what? A new weapon that is invisible? Raving lunatics, that's what they'll call us. They'll say we're so desperate to exonerate the Captain, we'll say *anything*.
And they would be correct. We have no evidence, only a theory which happens to fit the facts.
Assuming you're right, Mr. Spock, why would they fire on their own president?
Indeed.
This ship will be searched from bow to stern, Lieutenant Valeris, you'll be in charge.
Aye, sir.
I do not understand. If there *was* a ship underneath us, surely the assassins beamed aboard from *that* vessel, not Enterprise.

You're forgetting something, Mr. Chekov. According to out databanks, this ship fired those torpedoes. If we *did*, the killers are here. If we did *not*, whoever altered the databanks is here. In either case, what we are looking for *is* here.
What *are* we looking for, sir?
Lieutenant?
Two pairs of gravity boots.
